<p><strong>The global agriculture industry is facing its biggest changes in the postwar period,</strong> from shifts in consumer preferences to technology-enabled productivity improvements to turmoil in domestic and international markets. We have identified four trends that could greatly influence the direction of the agriculture sector in the coming years, for better and for worse:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>We will eat differently. </em>Developing markets are catching up to the protein-consumption levels of developed ones, and both are battling obesity. Should this trend accelerate, it could lead to increased demand for protein-rich foods and <a href="/industries/agriculture/our-insights/alternative-proteins-the-race-for-market-share-is-on">alternative-meat products</a>.</li>
    <li><em>We will source from different places.</em> New regions of food productionnotably sub-Saharan Africa,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="69f1b761-cf30-4354-85c3-0aa429c3df29"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="69f1b761-cf30-4354-85c3-0aa429c3df29" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/south-africas-bold-priorities-for-inclusive-growth">South Africas bold priorities for inclusive growth</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, April 2015.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="77dc6fad-31a5-494f-9032-7f3d4404fdff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="77dc6fad-31a5-494f-9032-7f3d4404fdff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/lions-on-the-move-realizing-the-potential-of-africas-economies">Lions on the move II: Realizing the potential of Africas economies</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, September 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> and East Asia<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="09e6f61e-c79a-4b65-84aa-afd1210a00fe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="09e6f61e-c79a-4b65-84aa-afd1210a00fe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/three-paths-to-sustained-economic-growth-in-southeast-asia">Southeast Asia at the crossroads: Three paths to prosperity</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, November 2014.</span></span></span></a></span>could emerge, spurred by lower energy costs and climate-related challenges in traditional agriculture geographies.</li>
    <li><em>We will produce food and we will trade differently. </em>Advances in agricultural technology will increase transparency and traceability across the value chain. This will likely result in increased efficiency, reduced waste, and shrinking profit margins.</li>
    <li><em>We will conduct trade with different rules.</em> Government intervention and subsidies could reshape market dynamics and have long-term effects on global commerce.</li>
</ul>
<p>Taken together, or in any combination, these trends will have ripple effects extending to every corner of the agriculture sector (see sidebar, Commodities and the four trends). Its imperative for stakeholders to factor the trendsand potential disruptioninto their strategic decisions to ensure a more resilient future. In the following article, we elaborate on the four trends, including a discussion of scenarios that might affect how the trends play out.</p>

transform: translate(0px, 100px);"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Commodities and the four trends</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__next-heading__ZYaa2">Continue to next section </div><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="button_id" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__arrow-down__JAGOH"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-lg___5rPck_990311c mck-arrow-down-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-sm-span-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-6 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-sticky__k5JFm"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__scroll-share__FVQ34"><div data-component="mdc-c-dropdown-menu" class="mdc-c-drop-down"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="floating-ui-1" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--default___f-hQM_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-share2-icon"></span><span>Share</span></button><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class=""></div></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__black-background__tPdB_"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Corn, soybeans, sugar, and wheat are the most traded crops as a percentage of global consumption.</strong> As a result, they are considerably exposed to the trends we describe in this article. The demand outlook to 2027 for these commodities remains tightly linked to an increasing global population and income growth in Asian emerging markets, notably China.</p>
<p>These four crops have flat cost curves, meaning that small changes in market dynamics, let alone the big changes that the four trends could prompt, can have an outsize effect on export competitiveness. It should also be noted that wheat is traded over shorter distances because it is widely produced across the world, so it would likely be less affected by disruptions than the other three crops.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<h2>We will eat differently</h2>
<p>Most people around the world eat more calories than they need (Exhibit 1). This is particularly true in developed countries in Europe and North America, although even some developing economies in Asia and South America see average individual caloric consumption above recommended levels. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the combination of increased caloric intake and decreased physical activity has caused worldwide obesity to nearly triple since 1975, and the majority of the worlds population lives in countries where noncommunicable diseases linked to overconsumption, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and cancer, kill more people than hunger.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="07863b36-8f2f-4d7f-a0dc-8aeb4750816f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="07863b36-8f2f-4d7f-a0dc-8aeb4750816f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Obesity and overweight, World Health Organization, updated February 16, 2018, www.who.int.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Most people are eating more calories than they should, especially in developed and some developing markets." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Meanwhile, as developing markets mature and gain wealth, their populations diets shift toward higher meat consumption. Indeed, our analysis shows how meat consumption stabilizes at higher levels of income compared with less costly food products that are based on sugar (Exhibit 2). Chinas booming middle class and rapid urbanization have thus been accompanied by a remarkable rise in meat consumption in recent years. According to McKinsey analysis, half of the increase in global meat consumption over the past decade can be attributed to China.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea805fde-baff-4ebc-979c-3c8f41e69c79"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea805fde-baff-4ebc-979c-3c8f41e69c79" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Justin Ahmed, Jeffrey Lorch, Liane Ong, and Jay Wolfgram, <a href="/industries/agriculture/our-insights/how-the-global-supply-landscape-for-meat-protein-will-evolve">How the global supply landscape for meat protein will evolve</a>, October 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In general, countries stabilize sugar consumption at lower levels of income than meat consumption." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>We have developed two scenarios related to what we eat that could affect the industry in the coming years.</p>
<h3>What if attacking obesity becomes a global priority?</h3>
<p>According to Euromonitor, sugar has moved to front and center in the healthy-eating debate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="76da3721-48a0-4376-b2cb-6d6df66e3412"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="76da3721-48a0-4376-b2cb-6d6df66e3412" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Pinar Hoafi, 8 food trends for 2018, Euromonitor International, March 16, 2018, blog.euromonitor.com.</span></span></span></a></span> A report from the EAT-Lancet Commission<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4da189d9-4fbd-47de-932e-9b21048367e3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4da189d9-4fbd-47de-932e-9b21048367e3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">EAT-Lancet Commission on Food, Planet, Health, eatforum.org.</span></span></span></a></span> argues  that to fight obesity, global consumption of fruits, vegetables, nuts, and legumes will have to double, and consumption of foods such as red meat and sugar will have to be reduced by more than 50 percent. In the United States, per-capita consumption of high-fructose corn syrup fell 40 percent from its peak, from 2000 to 2018.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dcbc7277-7833-48aa-af1e-fb5ea484d61b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dcbc7277-7833-48aa-af1e-fb5ea484d61b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">USDA.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Both push and pull factors played a role in its decline. Among the push factors are that many subnational US governments have implemented or are discussing regulations and taxes on soft drinks, including California, Illinois, and New York. As for pull factors, the boom in new juices, smoothies, and sports drinks provides consumers with alternatives to traditional carbonated beverages, which are high in high-fructose corn syrup in the United States.
</p>
<p>Should this movement continue, and obesity be seen as the major 21st-century threat to health, the international sugar market could be affected, potentially hitting exporting countries such as Australia, Brazil, India, and Thailand. It could also have an impact on biofuel markets, given the production relation between sugar and ethanol. If less sugar is consumed, more of it could be used for ethanol, increasing supply of the fuel and depressing its prices in the short run.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>A report from the EAT-Lancet Commission advocates that to fight obesity, global consumption of fruits, vegetables, nuts, and legumes will have to double, and consumption of foods such as red meat and sugar will have to be reduced by more than 50 percent.</p></blockquote></div>
<h3>What if meat 2.0 goes mainstream?</h3>
<p>The main reason for the rise of soybean production over the past two decades was an increase in meat consumption globally, particularly in China. To meet this growing demand, soybean production for use as animal feed grew, especially in North and South America. Total soybean exports nearly doubled in these geographies from 2008 to 2018, from 73 million tons to 143 million tons.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="881b128a-ea28-44c3-9e78-4ff8ddc74a89"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="881b128a-ea28-44c3-9e78-4ff8ddc74a89" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">OECD-FAO Agricultural Outlook 20192028.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This growth may level out as the rise in incomes slows in China and thus meat-consumption growth decelerates. Other effects include people turning toward healthier diets, growing intolerance to how animals are treated, and increased public awareness of the negative effect of livestock on climate change.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="baaab963-2673-4124-8cd1-fac1106e17fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="baaab963-2673-4124-8cd1-fac1106e17fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Annick de Witt, People still dont get the link between meat consumption and climate change, <em>Scientific American</em>, April 11, 2016, blogs.<span> </span>scientificamerican.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Indeed, mainstream consumers of meat are expected to remain the most relevant part of the market, but the definition of meat is expanding to include a variety of meat-replacement and alternative products dubbed meat 2.0. These products include, for example, cultured meats<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9db95f4a-e5bf-4f18-aa0c-0d025895532b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9db95f4a-e5bf-4f18-aa0c-0d025895532b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cultured meats are meats produced in labs from cell cultures.</span></span></span></a></span>the price of which dropped 99 percent from 2013 to 2017 and which have less of an effect on the climate than standard meat production.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fbde967d-d39d-426f-a27f-847ebd7fe00e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fbde967d-d39d-426f-a27f-847ebd7fe00e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Chase Purdy, In four years, the price of lab-grown meat has fallen by 99%. Theres still a long way to go, <em>Quartz</em>, June 5, 2017, qz.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/agriculture/how-we-help-clients">Agriculture Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<p>But before cultured meats hit the market, an even more significant piece of the meat-consumption market is quickly growing: <a href="/featured-insights/the-next-normal/the-future-of-food-meatless">meat-replacement products</a> made of, for example, soybean protein, potatoes, sunflower oil, and pea protein. Surveys suggest<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3f7f71bd-a475-48c1-a1c2-522d1bf7c295"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3f7f71bd-a475-48c1-a1c2-522d1bf7c295" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>A Survey of Consumer Perceptions of Plant-Based and Clean Meat in the USA, India, and China</em>, Frontiers in Sustainable Food Systems, <span> </span>February 27. 2019, frontiersin.org.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3dce6cde-3879-4aac-b883-39ead1def590"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3dce6cde-3879-4aac-b883-39ead1def590" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Niamh Michail, What do consumers really think of meat alternatives?, FoodNavigator, July 27, 2018, foodnavigator.com.</span></span></span></a></span> that the majority of the population would be inclined to try meat-replacement products, or vegetal meat. This fast-growing segment is attracting funding from venture capital as well as established companies, and initial public offerings of alternative-meat companies have begun.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f47a17c-743b-4f2b-abfa-f59b6c0b3481"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f47a17c-743b-4f2b-abfa-f59b6c0b3481" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joshua Franklin and Angela Moon, Impossible Foods raises $300 million with investors eager for bite of meatless burgers, <em>Reuters</em>, May 13, <span> </span>2019, Reuters.com; Kelsey Piper, Impossible Foods meatless burgers have made it a $2 billion company, <em>Vox</em>, May 13, 2019, vox.com. </span></span></span></a></span> According to one of these alternative-meat start-ups, 93 percent of its customers also buy animal meat. Increased production of artificial meat could be a factor in increasing the overall size of the global meat-protein market. In response, food and agriculture companies should consider whether, how, and to what extent to enter the alternative-meat market.</p>
<h2>We will source from different places</h2>
<p>The global landscape of food-producing regions will change. This could be a result of the <a href="/industries/agriculture/our-insights/agriculture-plays-a-critical-role-in-limiting-the-impact-of-climate-change">impact of climate change</a> (for example, drought and higher temperatures in some places) or reduced costs (for example, energy). Lower energy costs (Exhibit 3) can help make arable some areas that are now unfit for agriculture by cutting the cost of sourcing or desalinizing water and pumping it to land deprived of it.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex3-rev.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Declines in renewable energy costs could unlock new arable areas for agriculture." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex3-rev.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>We have developed two scenarios related to where we source food from that could affect the industry in the coming years.</p>
<h3>What if China doubles its soybean production or imports more from neighboring countries?</h3>
<p>China has grown into the worlds largest soybean importer. The main bottleneck to expansion of its internal agricultural production is water. However, if energy costs decrease enough to make desalinization economically feasible, then unused arable land could be made available through irrigation. This could significantly affect global trade: in 2018, <a href="/featured-insights/china/what-can-we-expect-in-china-in-2020">China</a> imported 91 million tons of soybeans. In a business-as-usual scenario, this amount would rise to 108 million tons by 2028.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea7899eb-b980-4889-a9fe-e5e5ef54457d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea7899eb-b980-4889-a9fe-e5e5ef54457d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">OECD-FAO Agricultural Outlook 20192028.</span></span></span></a></span> However, technological developments in energy and desalinization might enable new producers in China, its neighboring countries, and Africa to supply a significant portion of Chinas growing demand, therefore displacing some of the current Western exports to eastern Asia. If Chinas Western imports stay on par with 2018 levels, that would result in a 10 percent reduction in global trade volume.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="89d1acfa-5a9d-4631-a0cd-877f6136d4fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="89d1acfa-5a9d-4631-a0cd-877f6136d4fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">OECD-FAO Agricultural Outlook 20192028.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>What if Africa emerges as a major agricultural producer?</h3>
<p>Meanwhile, changes in other parts of the world could make places such as Africa more viable for increased agriculture production. The continent is <a href="/industries/agriculture/our-insights/winning-in-africas-agricultural-market">generally regarded as a wild card</a> in the agriculture industry. The potential is huge, but the continent faces significant challengesincluding access to energy and irrigation, as well as the need for basic infrastructurethat put its ascendance in question. Asian investors participation in infrastructure may become a deciding factor in accelerating the continents rise toward self-sufficiency rather than remaining a net importer, especially for sugar and corn. This would affect exporters into Africa, such as France, Russia, and the United States.</p>
<h2>We will produce food and we will trade differently</h2>
<p>Digital technologies are increasingly prevalent across the agricultural value chain, reducing information asymmetries, driving transparency, and boosting production yields to new highs. To date, farming technologies<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d0a87f6d-7b05-4a85-9902-1d03e89e90db"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d0a87f6d-7b05-4a85-9902-1d03e89e90db" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lutz Goedde, Maya Horii, and Sunil Sanghvi, <a href="/industries/chemicals/our-insights/pursuing-the-global-opportunity-in-food-and-agribusiness">Pursuing the global opportunity in food and agribusiness</a>, July 2015.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bd2c42da-733e-4944-a8d5-f7cb3d4ed1a8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bd2c42da-733e-4944-a8d5-f7cb3d4ed1a8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kevin Laczkowski, Asutosh Padhi, Niranjana Rajagopal, and Paolo Sandrone, <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/how-oems-can-seize-the-high-tech-future-in-agriculture-and-construction">How OEMs can seize the high-tech future in agriculture and <span> </span> construction</a>, March 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> have advanced the industry in four eras and continue to define the maturity of producing countries. For example, when it comes to maize productivity, Africa and India remain in the first stage, dubbed the green revolution, which is defined by the use of fertilizers and pesticides. Argentina, Brazil, and China are in the modern-agriculture phase, which involves new generations of crop-protection products and new methods of cultivation, for example, mechanization. The European Union and the United States have advanced to 21st-century agriculture, characterized <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-big-data-will-revolutionize-the-global-food-chain">by precision agriculture</a>for example, using advanced analytics to apply nutrients and crop-protection products at variable rates. In the coming years, only the producers that have mastered precision agriculture will be ready to take advantage of the fourth era, next-generation agriculture technologies. Though far-off, this era will feature the proliferation of biotechnologies, gene editing (such as CRISPR), and automation, including agricultural robots that will monitor fields and harvest crops.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="StatementDisruptor_mck-c-statement-disruptor__iOBdi mck-o-edge-to-edge" data-module-name="statement-disruptor"><div><div class="StatementDisruptor_mck-c-statement-disruptor__background-container__p_cFW"><div class="StatementDisruptor_mck-c-statement-disruptor__background-image-container__es__n"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-statement-disruptor-39EAB2CFAB9D488F9A85C67482C3494C" role="img" aria-label="In the coming years, only the producers that have mastered precision agriculture will be ready to take advantage of the fourth era, next-generation agriculture technologies."></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.1"></div></div></div><div class="StatementDisruptor_mck-c-statement-disruptor__content-container__2bGvV"><div class="StatementDisruptor_mck-c-statement-disruptor__content__KNhFy"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-13 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12"><div class="mck-c-statement-disruptor__title-container"><p class="StatementDisruptor_mck-c-statement-disruptor__text-content__7xNDN">In the coming years, only the producers that have mastered precision agriculture will be ready to take advantage of the fourth era, next-generation agriculture technologies.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<h3>What if digitization of the value chain eliminates information asymmetry?</h3>
<p>We see a future in which digital platforms enable full transparency and traceability across the food value chaincreating an environment in which actors in the value chain can more easily buy and sell to each other, compare prices, and review and rate suppliers. One current online agribusiness marketplace brings together those looking to buy and sell farm equipment, insurance, farmland, tools, and vehicles. This environment could lead to the emergence of online-trading platforms for agricultural productsrelying on virtual currency and financial-technology companies to foster the buying and selling of agricultural inputs.</p>
<p>This transparency could also decrease margins for intermediaries such as distributors and traders. In other industries, such as transportation, the surplus created by more value-chain transparency was transferred to end consumers. Indeed, trading margins of agriculture commodities have been shrinking, dropping from 15 percent in 1998 to 9 percent in 2018 (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c0455031-41af-4c52-9a90-9c8c5c44fcbf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c0455031-41af-4c52-9a90-9c8c5c44fcbf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Weighted averages of ADM, The Andersons, BayWa, Bunge, Graincorp, Olam International, and Sudzucker annual revenues. Source: McKinsey Corporate Performance Analytics.</span></span></span></a></span> Lower returns make the ability to be cost competitivewhich today is largely achieved through technology adoptioneven more relevant.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex4-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Trading margins of agricultural commodities traders have been shrinking." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex4-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>We will trade with different rules</h2>
<p>Subsidies and <a href="/mgi/overview/in-the-news/anger-over-tariffs-obscures-a-shift-in-patterns-of-global-trade">export tariffs</a> can change market dynamics and shift the competitive position of countries across the globe. Indeed, any manipulation of market dynamics can stack distortions on top of one another. For example, while export tariffs may give governments in certain regions extra funds in the short term, they also alter the cost competitiveness of producers in the cost curve and impact profit pools (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex5-rev.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Subsidies and tariffs might change the competitive position of a single exporting country in the cost curve but worsen the overall market dynamics." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/agriculture/our%20insights/agriculture%20sector%20preparing%20for%20disruption%20in%20the%20food%20value%20chain/svgz-foodmenu-ex5-rev.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>We have developed one scenario related to how we trade that could affect the industry in the coming years.</p>
<h3>What if we create a world of subsidies or a reverse in trade growth causes lower economic growth?</h3>
<p>The consequences of subsidies, export tariffs, and trade-growth reductions are felt hardest by exporters; as subsidies go to certain producers regardless of efficiency or productivity, already flat commodity cost curves get even flatter. Profit pools could be affected by 50 percent in some cases (Exhibit 5). The effect of these government actions could have a long-term impact on markets. Similarly, trade-restriction measures, if they continue to mount, could reduce overall economic growth, causing the rise in globally traded volumes of commodities to stall. As a result, the acceleration of protein consumption we discussed previously could slow down.</p>
<hr>
<p>Developments in climate change, trade wars, new technologies, and consumer choices could lead to a revolution in the way we eat, produce, source, and trade food. These potential disruptions to the food value chain pose risks to stakeholders in the agriculture sector, from growers, input providers, and traders to consumer-goods companies, investors, and policy makers. Its essential that the stakeholders take account of these trends in their strategies. Those that do will increase the chances of creating value, even in the face of disruption.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Mikael Djanian</strong> is an associate partner in McKinseys So Paulo office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/nelson-ferreira">Nelson Ferreira</a></strong> is a senior partner.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Eric Bartels, Lutz Goedde, Joshua Katz, Roberto Uchoa de Paula, and Yuito Yamada for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section chain","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"822aaac8-2fb6-44a4-84ab-6ba8bab68276","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Agriculture sector: Preparing for disruption in the food value chain"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Agriculture trends disrupting the food value chain"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Four trends could profoundly influence the direction of the  agriculture industry. Stakeholders, from farmers to governments, must take account of them in their planning."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Four agriculture industry trends could profoundly disrupt the food value chain. Stakeholders, from farmers to governments, must plan ahead."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-05-11T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe global agriculture industry is facing its biggest changes in the postwar period,\u003c/strong\u003e from shifts in consumer preferences to technology-enabled productivity improvements to turmoil in domestic and international markets. We have identified four trends that could greatly influence the direction of the agriculture sector in the coming years, for better and for worse:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe will eat differently. \u003c/em\u003eDeveloping markets are catching up to the protein-consumption levels of developed ones, and both are battling obesity. Should this trend accelerate, it could lead to increased demand for protein-rich foods and \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/alternative-proteins-the-race-for-market-share-is-on\"\u003ealternative-meat products\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe will source from different places.\u003c/em\u003e New regions of food production\u0026mdash;notably sub-Saharan Africa,[[footnote 1]][[footnote 2]] and East Asia[[footnote 3]]\u0026mdash;could emerge, spurred by lower energy costs and climate-related challenges in traditional agriculture geographies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe will produce food and we will trade differently. \u003c/em\u003eAdvances in agricultural technology will increase transparency and traceability across the value chain. This will likely result in increased efficiency, reduced waste, and shrinking profit margins.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe will conduct trade with different rules.\u003c/em\u003e Government intervention and subsidies could reshape market dynamics and have long-term effects on global commerce.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTaken together, or in any combination, these trends will have ripple effects extending to every corner of the agriculture sector (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Commodities and the four trends\u0026rdquo;). It\u0026rsquo;s imperative for stakeholders to factor the trends\u0026mdash;and potential disruption\u0026mdash;into their strategic decisions to ensure a more resilient future. In the following article, we elaborate on the four trends, including a discussion of scenarios that might affect how the trends play out.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eWe will eat differently\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost people around the world eat more calories than they need (Exhibit 1). This is particularly true in developed countries in Europe and North America, although even some developing economies in Asia and South America see average individual caloric consumption above recommended levels. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the combination of increased caloric intake and decreased physical activity has caused worldwide obesity to nearly triple since 1975, and the majority of the world\u0026rsquo;s population lives in countries where noncommunicable diseases linked to overconsumption, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and cancer, kill more people than hunger.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, as developing markets mature and gain wealth, their populations\u0026rsquo; diets shift toward higher meat consumption. Indeed, our analysis shows how meat consumption stabilizes at higher levels of income compared with less costly food products that are based on sugar (Exhibit 2). China\u0026rsquo;s booming middle class and rapid urbanization have thus been accompanied by a remarkable rise in meat consumption in recent years. According to McKinsey analysis, half of the increase in global meat consumption over the past decade can be attributed to China.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe have developed two scenarios related to what we eat that could affect the industry in the coming years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat if attacking obesity becomes a global priority?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to Euromonitor, sugar has moved to front and center in the healthy-eating debate.[[footnote 6]] A report from the EAT-Lancet Commission[[footnote 7]] argues  that to fight obesity, global consumption of fruits, vegetables, nuts, and legumes will have to double, and consumption of foods such as red meat and sugar will have to be reduced by more than 50 percent. In the United States, per-capita consumption of high-fructose corn syrup fell 40 percent from its peak, from 2000 to 2018.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth push and pull factors played a role in its decline. Among the push factors are that many subnational US governments have implemented or are discussing regulations and taxes on soft drinks, including California, Illinois, and New York. As for pull factors, the boom in new juices, smoothies, and sports drinks provides consumers with alternatives to traditional carbonated beverages, which are high in high-fructose corn syrup in the United States.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShould this movement continue, and obesity be seen as the major 21st-century threat to health, the international sugar market could be affected, potentially hitting exporting countries such as Australia, Brazil, India, and Thailand. It could also have an impact on biofuel markets, given the production relation between sugar and ethanol. If less sugar is consumed, more of it could be used for ethanol, increasing supply of the fuel and depressing its prices in the short run.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat if \u0026lsquo;meat 2.0\u0026rsquo; goes mainstream?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe main reason for the rise of soybean production over the past two decades was an increase in meat consumption globally, particularly in China. To meet this growing demand, soybean production for use as animal feed grew, especially in North and South America. Total soybean exports nearly doubled in these geographies from 2008 to 2018, from 73 million tons to 143 million tons.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis growth may level out as the rise in incomes slows in China and thus meat-consumption growth decelerates. Other effects include people turning toward healthier diets, growing intolerance to how animals are treated, and increased public awareness of the negative effect of livestock on climate change.[[footnote 10]] Indeed, mainstream consumers of meat are expected to remain the most relevant part of the market, but the definition of meat is expanding to include a variety of meat-replacement and alternative products dubbed \u0026ldquo;meat 2.0.\u0026rdquo; These products include, for example, \u0026ldquo;cultured meats\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 11]]\u0026mdash;the price of which dropped 99 percent from 2013 to 2017 and which have less of an effect on the climate than standard meat production.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eBut before cultured meats hit the market, an even more significant piece of the meat-consumption market is quickly growing: \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal/the-future-of-food-meatless\"\u003emeat-replacement products\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;made of, for example, soybean protein, potatoes, sunflower oil, and pea protein. Surveys suggest[[footnote 13]][[footnote 14]] that the majority of the population would be inclined to try meat-replacement products, or vegetal meat. This fast-growing segment is attracting funding from venture capital as well as established companies, and initial public offerings of alternative-meat companies have begun.[[footnote 15]] According to one of these alternative-meat start-ups, 93 percent of its customers also buy animal meat. Increased production of artificial meat could be a factor in increasing the overall size of the global meat-protein market. In response, food and agriculture companies should consider whether, how, and to what extent to enter the alternative-meat market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWe will source from different places\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe global landscape of food-producing regions will change. This could be a result of the \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/agriculture-plays-a-critical-role-in-limiting-the-impact-of-climate-change\"\u003eimpact of climate change\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(for example, drought and higher temperatures in some places) or reduced costs (for example, energy). Lower energy costs (Exhibit 3) can help make arable some areas that are now unfit for agriculture by cutting the cost of sourcing or desalinizing water and pumping it to land deprived of it.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe have developed two scenarios related to where we source food from that could affect the industry in the coming years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat if China doubles its soybean production or imports more from neighboring countries?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChina has grown into the world\u0026rsquo;s largest soybean importer. The main bottleneck to expansion of its internal agricultural production is water. However, if energy costs decrease enough to make desalinization economically feasible, then unused arable land could be made available through irrigation. This could significantly affect global trade: in 2018, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/china/what-can-we-expect-in-china-in-2020\"\u003eChina\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;imported 91 million tons of soybeans. In a business-as-usual scenario, this amount would rise to 108 million tons by 2028.[[footnote 16]] However, technological developments in energy and desalinization might enable new producers in China, its neighboring countries, and Africa to supply a significant portion of China\u0026rsquo;s growing demand, therefore displacing some of the current Western exports to eastern Asia. If China\u0026rsquo;s Western imports stay on par with 2018 levels, that would result in a 10 percent reduction in global trade volume.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat if Africa emerges as a major agricultural producer?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, changes in other parts of the world could make places such as Africa more viable for increased agriculture production. The continent is \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/winning-in-africas-agricultural-market\"\u003egenerally regarded as a wild card\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the agriculture industry. The potential is huge, but the continent faces significant challenges\u0026mdash;including access to energy and irrigation, as well as the need for basic infrastructure\u0026mdash;that put its ascendance in question. Asian investors\u0026rsquo; participation in infrastructure may become a deciding factor in accelerating the continent\u0026rsquo;s rise toward self-sufficiency rather than remaining a net importer, especially for sugar and corn. This would affect exporters into Africa, such as France, Russia, and the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWe will produce food and we will trade differently\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDigital technologies are increasingly prevalent across the agricultural value chain, reducing information asymmetries, driving transparency, and boosting production yields to new highs. To date, farming technologies[[footnote 18]][[footnote 19]] have advanced the industry in four \u0026ldquo;eras\u0026rdquo; and continue to define the maturity of producing countries. For example, when it comes to maize productivity, Africa and India remain in the first stage, dubbed the green revolution, which is defined by the use of fertilizers and pesticides. Argentina, Brazil, and China are in the modern-agriculture phase, which involves new generations of crop-protection products and new methods of cultivation, for example, mechanization. The European Union and the United States have advanced to 21st-century agriculture, characterized \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-big-data-will-revolutionize-the-global-food-chain\"\u003eby precision agriculture\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;for example, using advanced analytics to apply nutrients and crop-protection products at variable rates. In the coming years, only the producers that have mastered precision agriculture will be ready to take advantage of the fourth era, next-generation agriculture technologies. Though far-off, this era will feature the proliferation of biotechnologies, gene editing (such as CRISPR), and automation, including agricultural robots that will monitor fields and harvest crops.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[StatementDisruptor 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat if digitization of the value chain eliminates information asymmetry?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe see a future in which digital platforms enable full transparency and traceability across the food value chain\u0026mdash;creating an environment in which actors in the value chain can more easily buy and sell to each other, compare prices, and review and rate suppliers. One current online agribusiness marketplace brings together those looking to buy and sell farm equipment, insurance, farmland, tools, and vehicles. This environment could lead to the emergence of online-trading platforms for agricultural products\u0026mdash;relying on virtual currency and financial-technology companies to foster the buying and selling of agricultural inputs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis transparency could also decrease margins for intermediaries such as distributors and traders. In other industries, such as transportation, the surplus created by more value-chain transparency was transferred to end consumers. Indeed, trading margins of agriculture commodities have been shrinking, dropping from 15 percent in 1998 to 9 percent in 2018 (Exhibit 4).[[footnote 20]] Lower returns make the ability to be cost competitive\u0026mdash;which today is largely achieved through technology adoption\u0026mdash;even more relevant.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch2\u003eWe will trade with different rules\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubsidies and \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview/in-the-news/anger-over-tariffs-obscures-a-shift-in-patterns-of-global-trade\"\u003eexport tariffs\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can change market dynamics and shift the competitive position of countries across the globe. Indeed, any manipulation of market dynamics can stack distortions on top of one another. For example, while export tariffs may give governments in certain regions extra funds in the short term, they also alter the cost competitiveness of producers in the cost curve and\u0026nbsp;impact profit pools (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe have developed one scenario related to how we trade that could affect the industry in the coming years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat if we create a world of subsidies or a reverse in trade growth causes lower economic growth?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe consequences of subsidies, export tariffs, and trade-growth reductions are felt hardest by exporters; as subsidies go to certain producers regardless of efficiency or productivity, already flat commodity cost curves get even flatter. Profit pools could be affected by 50 percent in some cases (Exhibit 5). The effect of these government actions could have a long-term impact on markets. Similarly, trade-restriction measures, if they continue to mount, could reduce overall economic growth, causing the rise in globally traded volumes of commodities to stall. As a result, the acceleration of protein consumption we discussed previously could slow down.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDevelopments in climate change, trade wars, new technologies, and consumer choices could lead to a revolution in the way we eat, produce, source, and trade food. These potential disruptions to the food value chain pose risks to stakeholders in the agriculture sector, from growers, input providers, and traders to consumer-goods companies, investors, and policy makers. It\u0026rsquo;s essential that the stakeholders take account of these trends in their strategies. Those that do will increase the chances of creating value, even in the face of disruption.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-05-11T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/south-africas-bold-priorities-for-inclusive-growth\"\u003eSouth Africa\u0026rsquo;s bold priorities for inclusive growth\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;
